q1.question: What is coaxial cables usually made of?

q2.question: Who primarily uses coaxial cables?
q2.a: cable television companies and satellite communication systems.

q3.question: A coaxial cable is enclosed in what?

q4.question: Does a coaxial cable have a higher or lower signal to noise ratio then unshielded twisted pair, and why?
q4.answer: Yes it does, bcause it has an insulating jacket to protect it from unwanted noise. This is a Braided copper shielding.

q5.question: Can coaxial carry more data then untwisted pair? Explain your answer

q6.question: Why has twisted pair replaced coaxial in LANS?
q6.answer: Coax is physically harder to install, more expensive and harder to troubleshoot.

q7.answer: Outer Jacket, Braided Copper Sheilding, Plastic Insulation, Copper Conductor

q9.question: What are twisted-pair cables used for?
q9.answer: Telepone communications and most Ethernet networks.

q11.question: What is cross talk, and how do Twisted-'pair cables prevent this?
q11.fill in the blank: Cross talk is when signals for adjacent pairs for wires generate noise. Because each pair of wires is twisted, the electromagnetic fields they produce cancel out over short distances. By twisting the two conductors together, the direction of the interference flips with every twist. So, the induced noise from one part of the twist is canceled by the next, since it’s equal in magnitude but opposite in polarity.

multiple choice.A1: Crosstalk is when one cable’s signal reflects back into itself. Twisted-pair cables prevent it by twisting to match the impedance of the line.
multiple choice.A2: Crosstalk is static caused by moisture or poor grounding. Twisted-pair cables prevent it by using waterproof insulation to block noise.
multiple choice.A3: Crosstalk is when too many users share a network line. Twisted-pair cables stop it by using tighter insulation around each conductor.
multiple choice.A4: Crosstalk is when the electrical current weakens over distance. Twisted-pair cables prevent this by twisting to reduce resistance and maintain voltage.
multiple choice.A5: Crosstalk is when two devices transmit at the same time. Twisted-pair cables stop it by separating each signal onto different frequencies.
multiple choice.A6: Crosstalk is when signals from one pair interfere with another. Twisted-pair cables prevent it by reversing the wire positions so electromagnetic fields cancel each other out.

q12.question: What is the most common variety of twisted-pair cabling

multiple choice.A6: Direct-burial cable

q13.question: UTP protects against electromagnetic interference (EMI) and/or radio frequency interference (RFI)

multiple choice.A1: True – the twisting of UTP wires completely blocks external interference.
multiple choice.A2: True – UTP has an internal foil shield around each wire pair.
multiple choice.A3: True – UTP includes both shielding and grounding to reduce interference.
multiple choice.A4: False – UTP has no shielding and relies only on twisting to reduce, not block, interference.
multiple choice.A5: False – UTP prevents interference through fiber-optic isolation.
multiple choice.A6: False – UTP includes a metal braid that cancels external signals.

q14.question: UTP cable consists of how many pairs of color-coded wires that have been twisted together and then encased in a flexible plastic sheath that protects from minor physical damage.

q15.question: Shielded twisted-pair (STP) was designed to provide better protection against EMI and RFI.

multiple choice.A1: True – STP includes shielding that helps block external interference such as EMI and RFI.
multiple choice.A2: False – STP does not use any shielding and relies only on twisting like UTP.
multiple choice.A3: False – STP is mainly designed for long-distance transmission, not interference protection.
multiple choice.A4: False – STP is a type of fiber-optic cabling that prevents signal loss.
multiple choice.A5: False – STP cables are unshielded and primarily used for home telephone wiring.
multiple choice.A6: False – STP cables reduce crosstalk but are unaffected by EMI or RFI.

q16.question: Each Shielded twisted-pair (STP) wrapped in their own internal foil shield.

multiple choice.A6: There is no such thing as shielded twised-pair

q17.question: The pairs of twisted wires in a Shielded twisted-pair (STP) are only shelided once, one for each pair.

multiple choice.A6: There is no such thing as shielded twised-pair

q18.question: Both UTP and STP cables are terminated with what type of connector?

multiple choice.A6: HDMI

q19.question: Compared to UTP cable, STP cable is significantly more expensive and difficult to install.

multiple choice.A4: only when used in short distances
multiple choice.A5: only when used for fiber systems
multiple choice.A6: depends on the network speed

q20.question: If a Shielded twisted-pair (STP) cable is improperly grounded, what can happen?
q20.fill in the blank: The shield may act as an antenna and pick up unwanted signals.

multiple choice.A1: The shield may act as an antenna and pick up unwanted signals.
multiple choice.A2: The cable will automatically block all interference.
multiple choice.A3: The signal strength will permanently increase.
multiple choice.A4: The cable will lose its physical shielding.
multiple choice.A5: The connector will short out the signal pairs.
multiple choice.A6: The shield will convert EMI into usable data.

q21.question: What is the maximum distance limitation for UTP cabling used for data?

multiple choice.A6: 200 meters (660 feet)

true and false.question: Is the maximum distance limitation for UTP cabling used for data 330 meters?

q22.question: What speed and frequency does Category 5e (Cat 5e) UTP cable support?

multiple choice.A6: 10 Gb/s at 1 GHz

true and false.question: Category 5e (Cat 5e) UTP cable supports 100 Mb/s at 100 MHz

q23.question: Which feature helps Cat 6 UTP cables reduce EMI and RFI better than Cat 5e?
q23.fill in the blank: A plastic divider that separates wire pairs inside the cable.

multiple choice.A2: A plastic divider that separates wire pairs inside the cable.
multiple choice.A3: Extra outer insulation made of foil wrap.
multiple choice.A4: Built-in ferrite filters at both ends.
multiple choice.A5: Braided metal shielding over each conductor.
multiple choice.A6: Additional grounding wire inside the jacket.

true and false.question: A plastic divider helps cat 6 UTP cables reduce EMI and RFI better than Cat 5e.

q24.question: What is special about plenum-rated UTP cables?
q24.fill in the blank: They are made from plastic that retards fire and produces less smoke.

multiple choice.A1: They are made from plastic that retards fire and produces less smoke.
multiple choice.A2: They are waterproof and designed for outdoor burial.
multiple choice.A3: They include an internal copper braid for extra shielding.
multiple choice.A4: They are designed for high-speed data centers only.
multiple choice.A5: They use glass fibers instead of copper conductors.
multiple choice.A6: They require special connectors that vent heat.

q25.question: Which twisted-pair wiring scheme places the green pair first in the connector pinout?

multiple choice.A6: Straight-through cable

true and false.question: T568A wiring scheme places the green pair first in the connector pinout.

q26.question: Which twisted-pair wiring scheme places the orange pair first in the connector pinout?

multiple choice.A6: Straight-through cable

true and false.question: T568B wiring scheme places the orange pair first in the connector pinout.

multiple choice.A6: O,OW,BL,BLW,G,GW,BW,B

q28.question: Why is fiber-optic cable not affected by electromagnetic or radio frequency interference (EMI/RFI)?
q28.fill in the blank: Because it uses light to transmit signals instead of electricity.

multiple choice.A1: Because it uses light to transmit signals instead of electricity.
multiple choice.A2: Because it uses heavy shielding around the copper wires.
multiple choice.A3: Because it operates at lower frequencies than electrical cables.
multiple choice.A4: Because it has built-in filters that block interference.
multiple choice.A5: Because the cladding layer absorbs external radio waves.
multiple choice.A6: Because it transmits power instead of data.

true and false.question: Fiber-optic cables are immune to EMI and RFI because they use light, not electricity, to transmit signals.

q29.question: What are two key advantages of fiber-optic cables compared to copper cables?
q29.fill in the blank: They carry clearer signals over longer distances with greater bandwidth.

multiple choice.A1: They carry clearer signals over longer distances with greater bandwidth.
multiple choice.A2: They are cheaper and easier to install than copper cables.
multiple choice.A3: They are thicker and can carry more electrical current.
multiple choice.A4: They require no connectors or termination points.
multiple choice.A5: They can only be used for short indoor runs.
multiple choice.A6: They rely on electromagnetic fields for higher capacity.

true and false.question: Fiber-optic cables can transmit data over longer distances and with greater bandwidth than copper cables.

q30.question: Despite being very thin, why are optical fibers considered durable and strong?
q30.fill in the blank: Because the properties of the core and cladding make them strong and resistant to damage.

multiple choice.A1: Because the properties of the core and cladding make them strong and resistant to damage.
multiple choice.A2: Because they contain a steel wire running through the center.
multiple choice.A3: Because they are coated with layers of copper shielding.
multiple choice.A4: Because they are made of flexible plastic instead of glass.
multiple choice.A5: Because they are thicker than copper cables.
multiple choice.A6: Because they are filled with gel that prevents breakage.

true and false.question: Optical fibers are durable because the core and cladding materials provide strength despite their thin size.

q31.question: In fiber-optic communication, what allows multiple data streams to travel through the same cable at the same time?

multiple choice.A6: Optical Phase Separation (OPS)

true and false.question: Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) allows multiple data streams to be transmitted simultaneously over a single optical fiber using different light wavelengths.

q32.question: What is the purpose of the jacket in an optical fiber cable?
q32.fill in the blank: It protects the fiber from abrasion, moisture, and other contaminants.

multiple choice.A1: It protects the fiber from abrasion, moisture, and other contaminants.
multiple choice.A2: It reflects light back into the fiber core for data transmission.
multiple choice.A3: It carries the light signals along the center of the cable.
multiple choice.A4: It strengthens the cladding and prevents signal loss.
multiple choice.A5: It converts light pulses back into electrical signals.
multiple choice.A6: It reduces electromagnetic interference in copper cores.

true and false.question: The outer jacket of an optical fiber cable protects it from abrasion, moisture, and contaminants.

q33.question: What is the purpose of the strengthening material in an optical fiber cable?
q33.fill in the blank: It provides tensile strength and prevents the fiber from breaking when pulled.

multiple choice.A1: It provides tensile strength and prevents the fiber from breaking when pulled.
multiple choice.A2: It directs light into the fiber core for transmission.
multiple choice.A3: It reflects light to maintain total internal reflection.
multiple choice.A4: It absorbs stray light and converts it into heat.
multiple choice.A5: It keeps the core at a stable temperature.
multiple choice.A6: It improves signal speed by reducing attenuation.

true and false.question: The strengthening material in an optical fiber cable prevents damage from pulling or bending.

q34.question: What is the function of the buffer layer in an optical fiber cable?
q34.fill in the blank: It cushions and protects the fiber core and cladding from physical stress.

multiple choice.A1: It cushions and protects the fiber core and cladding from physical stress.
multiple choice.A2: It carries the optical signal through the center of the fiber.
multiple choice.A3: It reflects light back toward the core.
multiple choice.A4: It provides tensile strength to the cable.
multiple choice.A6: It increases bandwidth by separating wavelengths.

true and false.question: The buffer layer protects the core and cladding from mechanical damage or bending stress.

q35.question: What is the purpose of the cladding in an optical fiber cable?
q35.fill in the blank: It reflects light back into the core to maintain total internal reflection.

multiple choice.A1: It reflects light back into the core to maintain total internal reflection.
multiple choice.A2: It protects the cable from moisture and abrasion.
multiple choice.A3: It carries the main optical signal through the fiber.
multiple choice.A4: It converts light back into electrical signals.
multiple choice.A5: It provides tensile strength for pulling and installation.
multiple choice.A6: It reduces electrical interference from nearby cables.

true and false.question: The cladding layer keeps the light contained in the core through total internal reflection.

q36.question: What is the role of the core in an optical fiber cable?
q36.fill in the blank: It is the central glass region that carries the light signals.

multiple choice.A1: It is the central glass region that carries the light signals.
multiple choice.A2: It provides protection against moisture and heat.
multiple choice.A3: It reflects light back to the source to prevent loss.
multiple choice.A4: It strengthens the outer layers of the fiber.
multiple choice.A5: It contains metallic wires that conduct the signal.
multiple choice.A6: It absorbs unwanted wavelengths of light.

true and false.question: The core is the central part of the optical fiber where light travels to transmit data.

q37.question: What is the main difference between Single-Mode Fiber (SMF) and Multi-Mode Fiber (MMF)?
q37.fill in the blank: SMF uses a small core and a laser light source; MMF uses a larger core and an LED light source.

multiple choice.A1: SMF uses a small core and a laser light source; MMF uses a larger core and an LED light source.
multiple choice.A2: SMF uses copper conductors while MMF uses glass.
multiple choice.A3: SMF carries multiple light paths while MMF carries only one.
multiple choice.A4: SMF is only used for LANs, while MMF is used for long-distance telephony.
multiple choice.A5: SMF uses thicker cladding to reduce dispersion; MMF has none.
multiple choice.A6: SMF and MMF both use the same light source but have different coatings.

true and false.question: Single-mode fiber uses a laser and a small core to transmit one path of light, while multi-mode fiber uses LEDs and a larger core for multiple light paths.

q38.question: What is the typical glass core diameter of a single-mode fiber cable?

multiple choice.A6: 25 microns

true and false.question: The core diameter of a single-mode fiber is typically 9 microns.

q39.question: What is the typical glass core diameter of a multimode fiber cable?

multiple choice.A6: 200 microns

true and false.question: A multimode fiber typically has a core diameter of 50 or 62.5 microns.

q40.question: Which type of fiber is better suited for long-distance communication over several kilometers?

multiple choice.A6: Shielded twisted pair (STP)

true and false.question: Single-mode fiber is used for long-distance communication because it produces a single straight light path with minimal dispersion.

q41.question: Which type of fiber is commonly used in LANs and supports distances of a few hundred meters?

multiple choice.A6: Coaxial cable

true and false.question: Multi-mode fiber is used in LAN environments and shorter campus runs because it uses low-cost LED transmitters.
